attention2.ptxt: This fault can result in a rapid and significant fouling of the diesel particulate filter.

item.ptxt: Conditions for applying fault finding procedures to stored faults:
The fault is declared present after the engine is started or following a road test.
If the fault is present:
Turbocharging is no longer authorized.
The EGR function is inhibited.
The Injection warning light (gravity 1 warning light) is lit.
Use service wire for all operations on the ECM connectors.
Order of priority in the event of more than one fault:
Firstly, deal with fault DTC P1431: Clogged Diesel Particulate Filter Failures:F9Q if it is present or stored.

entry.ptxt: Displaying on SUZUKI scan tool
Detecting condition
D1
Pressure too low
D2
Pressure too high

servinfosub.title: Troubleshooting for D1: Pressure too low

entry.ptxt: Check the boost pressure sensor connections.
Check the connections of the boost pressure control solenoid valve.
Check the ECM connections.
Repair if necessary.
Check the sealing of the high pressure air circuit:

item.ptxt: Disconnected or pierced pipes.
Pressure sensor disconnected or poorly fitted (seal present).
Intercooler pierced (to check the intercooler: with the vehicle stationary, stabiles the engine speed between 3500 to 4000 rpm and check there are no leaks).

entry.ptxt: Check the conformity of the turbocharging pressure signal and perform Test 5 and 6 of Fault Finding-Tests referring to Test 5: Variable Geometry Turbocharger Control:F9Q and Test 6: Rotating Part of a Turbocharger:F9Q .
Check that the turbocharger and its control circuit are working:

item.ptxt: With the engine switched OFF, make sure the control rod is in the resting position.
Start the engine and make sure that the control rod operates to the high stop. (when the engine stops, the control rod must return to the resting position).
If the control shaft does not move correctly, carry out the following checks:
Vacuum pressure command check:
Disconnect the solenoid valve intake hose and connect it to a vacuum pressure gauge.
Start the engine and stabilize it at idle speed.
If the vacuum pressure does not reach 70 – 90 kPa (0.7 – 0.9 kg/cm², 9.9 – 12.8 psi): check the vacuum pressure circuit from the vacuum pump.
Stop the engine, reconnect the inlet hoses and go to Step 2.
Solenoid valve control check:
Disconnect the solenoid valve outlet hose.
Start the engine and stabilize it at idle speed.
Place your hand on the solenoid valve and block the outlet connection with your thumb.
If there is no detectable vibration of the solenoid valve, check that the ECM output is working correctly (Refer to DTC P0033: Boost Pressure Control Solenoid Valve Control Circuit:F9Q D1).
Solenoid valve functioning check:
Attach the pressure gauge to the solenoid valve outlet connection.
Start the engine and stabilize it at idle speed.
If the vacuum pressure does not reach 70 – 90 kPa (0.7 – 0.9 kg/cm², 9.9 – 12.8 psi), replace the boost pressure control solenoid valve.

servinfosub.title: Troubleshooting for D2: Pressure too high

entry.ptxt: Check the boost pressure sensor connections.
Check the connections of the boost pressure control solenoid valve.
Check the ECM connections.
Repair if necessary.
Check the conformity of the turbocharging pressure signal. (Refer to “Turbo Pressure” on Data List of SUZUKI scan tool).
Make sure the turbocharging limit solenoid valve is not blocked open:

item.ptxt: With ignition switch OFF, disconnect the inlet and outlet hoses from the solenoid valve.
Connect a vacuum pump to the inlet union and apply a vacuum.
If the vacuum pressure is not maintained: replace the boost pressure control solenoid valve.

entry.ptxt: Check that the turbocharger control rod has not seized:

item.ptxt: With the engine stopped, make sure the turbocharger control shaft is in the rest position.
Apply a vacuum of 70 – 90 kPa (0.7 – 0.9 kg/cm², 9.9 – 12.8 psi), to the hose connecting the turbocharger control diaphragm.
If the diaphragm holds the vacuum pressure, check the movement and setting of the turbocharger control rod referring to Turbocharger Assembly Inspection:F9Q .

entry.ptxt: If the control rod is seized, replace the turbocharger.
If the fault persists, perform Test 5 and 6 of Fault Finding-Tests referring to Test 5: Variable Geometry Turbocharger Control:F9Q and Test 6: Rotating Part of a Turbocharger:F9Q .
